text: It's a windy march night in Chicago as CONOR O'NEILL climbs the steps of St. John's church. He pauses at the top of the stairs to take a long pull off a bottle in a brown bag. He enters the dark church.

CONOR pours himself into the last pew and unhooks the bow-tie of his rented tux. He's more exhausted than any 29 year old needs to be. A PRIEST leaving the church spots Conor and approaches him. The PRIEST is wearing street clothes and carries his formal work clothes an a hanger.

I gotta lock up son. CONOR nods in understanding while not breaking his drunken stare. The PRIEST senses CONOR's unhappiness. PRIEST (cont'd) You looking for faith? Forgiveness? CONOR gets up to leave. He looks at the Priest.
I'm looking for Milwaukee to beat the spread. CONOR leaves the church.
CONOR bolster's his courage by finishing the bagged pint and tossing it in the alley. He exhales before entering.
The typical Irish bar is alive with the sounds and smells of basketball and stale beer. Heads turn when they see CONOR enter, obviously an unwelcome regular. The bartender grabs CONOR by the jacket.
Conor are you nuts? CONOR pulls free and grabs a bowl of nuts off the bar. CONOR flings the nuts on the ground.
These are nuts. CONOR stumbles into a bar patron who shoves him out of the way. It's clear in the light that CONOR is drunk and probably has been all day. The BARTENDER has caught up to him.
Duffy's here, you better have his money.
I got it. The BARTENDER looks incredulously at CONOR who fesses up. CONOR (cont'd) I'm gonna have it, what's the score?
You're into Duffy for at least 5 grand, who gave you an account?
I laid 6 grand with Barber, to get me even. CONOR has locked his drunken eyes on the TV above the bar that barks out the Bulls game.
Bulls by 7.
I got Milwaukee gettin' eleven.
Two minutes to go.
Yeah baby, keep the clock runnin'. A young guy wearing an identical tux appears next to CONOR. This is JIIMMY. Behind him are two BRIDE'S MAIDS in poofy peach satin gowns.
I can't believe you, you split Mikey's wedding to come to Duffy's. CONOR doesn't even acknowledge his fellow groomsman as he addresses the TV.
Stop! What are they fouling him for?! JIMMY shakes his head but stays with CONOR. CONOR is locked on the TV. CONOR (cont'd) C'mon there's only a minute left it's over.
Jordan's hit 16 free throws in a row. That's 17.
Bulls by nine, hang on. Just hang on. DUFFY is a big burly Irish guy who comes out of a back office lead by the BARTENDER who obviously tipped him off about CONOR.
You didn't bet the Barber with my money? Right O'Neill? You're not that stupid.

Shut up Duffy, in 18 seconds you'll have your money. They all study the screen. Jordan steals the ball and attempts to run the court but is tackled by Ray Allen. CONOR (cont'd) That's okay even if he makes them both, it's eleven. I push. I'm even.
Flagrant foul, he shoots one for that first. CONOR throws his hands in the air and hollers his frustration.
That's bullshit!

That's 18 in a row. We watch the screen now as Jordan is smiling, taunting the Milwaukee Bucks as he stands on the line. Six seconds left with two free throws to go and the Bulls up 10. JORDAN launches the shot, it hits the front of the rim, hops over it, hits the back board and falls through the hoop. The ugliest free throw in history. CONOR nearly jumps out of his skin.

How the hell did that fall?!  JORDAN laughs at his own luck and resets for his last attempt. He sets, throws, nothing but net. BULLS by 12, the Bucks in-bound the ball and immediately begin shaking hands as they let the last couple of seconds tick off the clock. CONOR has gone silent as he instinctively starts drinking someone else's scotch off the bar. CONOR gets shoved by the man he stole the drink from. DUFFY begins to approach him. CONOR makes his way towards the door.
Grab him! CONOR rushes out the door and into the street. He takes off but a side door opens and the BARTENDER grabs him.

Get off a me. The BARTENDER squeezes him with his forearm. CONOR (cont'd) That's a hairy arm, I bet you shave your ass. The BARTENDER punches CONOR in the head with his free hand. CONOR wobbles from the blow but the BARTENDER keeps him standing. The bar has emptied to the street as DUFFY approaches CONOR. DUFFY clocks CONOR blind side and he drops like a rag doll from the grip of the BARTENDER.

I'm first O'Neill, you pay me first. The crowd is silent as they watch the drunk and now injured CONOR attempt to regain his feet. It's like watching a two year old walk as CONOR takes a stumbly step before standing upright. He addresses the assembly.

You wanna beat my ass? CONOR stumbles towards a parked car, he violently punches his hand through the driver side window. The crowd is motionless as he again turns to them, blood pouring from his hand. He howls now...

head_text.subj: NO ONE CAN KICK MY ASS BETTER

text: CONOR careens towards the crowd wildly waving his bloody hand. He suddenly changes course and lowers his head, ramming it through the window of Duffy's bar. To the gallery's surprise, CONOR rises unsteadily and makes a lame lunge at the crowd before falling almost face first an the pavement. JIMMY rushes to him and the crowd seems to disperse. DUFFY and the BARTENDER stand over CONOR's body. We hear the sound of sirens growing closer as we fade out.
The classic jail sound of metal hitting metal wakes CONOR who's been asleep sitting on the floor. He lifts his head from his knees and stares out at a familiar voice.
Conor, it's Ticky. IT'S

TICKY is a thirty-some year old ticket scalper who wears a quilted BULL's jacket and a BULL's National Champs painter's cap backwards.  A COP leads CONOR from his small holding cell. We now see that the blood stains on the raffle of his rented tux shirt match the makeshift bandage on his right hand. The large square bandaid on his forehead doesn't quite cover the scrape that's now marked with dark purple blood crust.
The COP pulls CONOR by the handcuffs to a large wooden bench in the lobby. TICKY watches as the COP routinely cuffs CONOR to the iron arm of the bench. CONOR offers in a weak voice...
Ticky, did you call my sister? TICKY leans close to CONOR in an effort to hear him. CONOR (cont'd) Did you call my sister?
Damn, you got zactly's breath?
Zactly's breath?
Your breath smells zactly like your ass. Damn, that's nasty.
Where's my sister?
She's comin' to get you, but came for the tickets.
Which ones?
You got two pair on the floor for the Bulls Rockets.
Yeah but you're not in on those remember? I'm gonna hawk those myself, the game's not till 7.
It's 5.
What?
Just tell me where they are.

Shit, under the uh...religious statue on my dresser. TICKY's already leaving. CONOR (cont'd) Wait, Ticky I want 1200, Ticky! CONOR slumps against the wall, he pulls his head back in pain. We hear the sound of pointy heels clicking pertly an the ground. KERRY O'NEILL appears with her older fiancée FRANK TORTORICI. KERRY is 23 going on 40 with over done nails and jewelry. FRANK is 40 going on 60 with a nebulous connection to the construction business in urban Chicago. KERRY stares disapprovingly at her older brother
This is gonna cost Frank eight hundred and fifty dollars. (commanding Frank)  Frankie go pay the guy. FRANK jumps to obey KERRY's command.
Frank, I really-
This is the last time, you're scarin' me Conor. You're just like Dad it breaks my heart -
I'm not just like Dad!
Yeah?! Duffy called the house today and said you smashed up his bar sounds like dad to me!
Kerry -

How many tickets you gonna scalp to pay for that? Huh? You'll be scalping tickets for Barney and Friends on ice, I swear to God. KERRY starts walking away as the COP returns with FRANK to uncuff CONOR from the bench.

We see CONOR get out of FRANK's late model Buick and make his way up the stoop of an apartment building in Rogers Park. An extremely modest neighborhood that sets the border between the exquisite Gold Coast and the ghetto ghost town of the Cabrini Green housing projects.

We hear the shower running as we pan the small one bedroom apartment. A cheap lamp lights the statue of Mary Magdalen standing an the desk. An old wooden color console TV playing a basketball game lights the rest of the cluttered room. A double mattress on the floor is at home with the sneakers and other clothes that take up most of the walking space. A Julius Erving poster inhabits the otherwise sparse walls. It appears as though CONOR has lived here a long time with no attempts to decorate. The shower stops and we can now hear the sound of the TV playing a post game show. CONOR steps from the bathroom wearing a CUBS beach towel around his waist, obviously a give away from a promotional day at Wrigley. CONOR holds a hand towel to the cut on his forehead. The doorbell rings. CONOR is immediately wary, he grabs an aluminum softball bat and steps to the side of the door.
Yeah?
It's Ticky, let me in. CONOR tosses the bat silently on the bed and begins unlocking the door.

Ticky, thank God, I really need that money... (as he opens the door) How much did you get for the tickets? CONOR opens the door to see TICKY get shoved aside by TwO GUYS. They immediately pin the toweled CONOR against the wall.
O'Neill, you remember me?
They grabbed me outside the United Center-
Barber's son.
O'Neill, do you even remember making that call from Michael Pistone's wedding?
Get off a me.
You spoke to me, and you said "It's O'Neill number 55 what's my limit?" I checked number 55 and I saw it had a six grand limit. CONOR shoves him but BARBER'S SON slams against the wall.
I took your six grand on Milwaukee and it went down so I asked my dad about O'Neill on account 55 and he said the guy on that account died six months ago.
Tell the Barber-
You bet six grand on your dead father's account, and now you owe my very alive, very pissed off father 6600. him harder BARBER'S SON pins him further up the wall.

C'mon let me down I'm ina towel would you relax, I'm not goin' anywhere. BARBER'S SON lets him down but stands in his face. CONOR (cont'd) I'm gonna pay him, Ticky give him the 1200 from tonight and well go from there. TICKY looks to CONOR with an apologetic smile.
I rolled it on the Bulls tonight on my own number with Duffy.
What?
I was gonna give 'ya the 2400 when it covered.
Bulls won by three, spread was five, same old stories with you guys, if this, if that...forget it, I need some money.
Here I'll give you everything I got. CONOR pulls a crinkled hand of bills from his rented tux pants. The other thug, GINO, counts it.
47 dollars. BARBER'S SON now grabs the bat and swings it against the wall. It makes an easy gash, he continues talking as if nothing just happened.
Tell me what to do?

Either I'll get a loan and pay someone else the juice every week or you can put me on a payment and I'll pay you the juice, you tell me. BARBER's son thinks it over, he grabs the bills from the other THUG.
You owe 6600, you pay me...5700 a week until I say stop.
That's ridiculous, 400. BARBER'S SON silently accepts his counter offer and then points the bat at him.

Bring it to the barber shop, but don't make me come back up here. I'm serious, please don't make me come back here. The BARBER'S SON'S plea seems soft but deadly serious. They leave. TICKY turns to CONOR who waves his hands making him leave with out saying a word. CONOR shuts and locks his door.

The business district teems with the foot traffic of well dressed professionals. CONOR sifts through this stream in casual clothes and a fishing hat properly angled to cover the bandaged gash on his forehead. He pauses to look up the face of the tall bank building he's about to enter. He goes in.
CONOR looks a bit out of place in the reception area of this white collar money circus. A CUTE RECEPTIONIST blushes for him as he approaches her.
I'm Conor O'Neill, I have a 11:30 with James Devlin.
Does he know what it's regarding?
The purchase of Wrigley field and the firing of sassy receptionists who wear aerobic sneakers to work and think that guys in fishing hats are sexy but dangerous.

(completely thrown) Just a minute. (into headset) Mr. O'Neill is here for his 11:30 with Mr. Devlin. Ok, yes. (to Conor) Right down that corridor Mr. O'Neill. CONOR walks in the direction her hand is pointing.

We recognize the man behind the desk as JIMMY, the other groomsman in a tux at Duffy's bar. He now wears a serious, conservative business suit complete with suspenders. JIMMY leaves CONOR standing in the doorway off his glass walled office. CONOR feels self-conscious with his fishing hat and bandages. JIMMY gets off the phone.
Mr. O'Neill, on time for your 11:30, uncommon for you, it must be important.

Yeah, Jimmy, I'm sorry about the other night after the wedding... CONOR waits for JIMMY to jump in, he doesn't. CONOR (cont'd) At Duffy's y'know, I was slightly over-served and uh... JIMMY continues to smile smugly at CONOR who we begin to feel sweating. CONOR (cont'd) I wanted to apologize.
Is that why you came down here?
No, I mean yes, it is but I also came because of what happened.
What happened?
You know the bet I had went down, and I busted up Duffy's bar a little and I uh kinda dug myself a big hole.
Yeah, I would imagine.
So what d'ya think?
About what? CONOR sighs and shifts his feet, he is burning in shame.
Can you help me out?
Help you with what?
Jimmy, you know why I came down here.
I need to hear you say it so I get it loud and clean CONOR digs deep and lays out what's left of his pride.
Can you lend me 12 grand? JIMMY lets the moment resonate.
You need to bury your father again?
What?!
Did you dig the guy up?
You're sick.
Me?! Five months ago you're in here cryin' for 5 grand to bury your old man. I talked to Scott Mahoney at Mikey's  wedding seems he also lent you 5 grand to bury the guy.
I'm gonna pay Mahoney back -
I don't care how much you owe Mahoney -
It's just right now I'm really up against it with Duffy and the Barber -

And I really don't give a shit how much you owe the bookies - CONOR starts out. JIMMY (cont'd) Wait, come back in. CONOR does. JIMMY (cont'd) Close the door. What's with you? You're the only one left at Duffy's. I'm gone, Mikey's gone, Mahoney. What are you doin'? Hangin' around with Ticky Tobin scalpin' tickets and bettin' games? Selfish, I can't believe I'm gonna do this for you. This is the last time. JIMMY starts writing a check.
(relieved) I'm done betting and I swear I'm gonna pay you back-
No you're not, you never do, so don't even say it. You never follow through on anything.
Who said that? Mahoney? JIMMY hands him a check, CONOR snatches it and studies the amount. CONOR has
This might actually help you.
This is only 500 bucks.
I know, you're gonna coach a kids baseball team with me.
Jimmy you don't understand how serious my situation is -
I'm gonna pay you 500 a week for the next 10 weeks, that's week one. no choice in the matter.
Jimmy I ain't good with kids.
I do this to give something back to the community. You don't wanna do it, gimme the check back. CONOR stands in the doorway, he's got no choice.
I'll see you at the field tomorrow, 3:30.
Where is it? JIMMY's now rushing him out.
That field on 1150 Carson, 3:30. CONOR's face goes blank.
That's really South on Carson are you sure it's-
Yeah, 1150 Carson it's behind the Oscar Meyer plant. JIMMY pushes him out the door, CONOR talks through the glass wall.

No, the only thing behind the Oscar Meyer plant is Cabrini Green. The projects. JIMMY has waved his last goodbye with a smile as he's jumped on a phone call. JIMMY pulls the blinds and CONOR looks around to see the office smiling at him. He realizes now that 500 a week might be a billion dollars short.

CARSON FIELD is surrounded by the ugly buildings of the failing Cabrini housing projects. The neighborhood looks and feels as dangerous as it is. A ghost town of unemployment, people stay off the streets day or night. CONOR makes his way across the beaten grass of Cabrini Baseball field. He wears an old Cubs hat as the only modification from his typical outfit that consists of work pants and black shoes.  It's still cool in March so his leather coat is appropriate. He sees a group of kids near a worn back stop with a wooden set of bleachers nearby. CONOR makes his way to the group but opts for a spot on the bleachers when he doesn't see JIMMY. We get a closer look at the kids who all appear to be between 9 and 12. There's probably 7 kids total who are all actively doing something counter productive. A little kid chases a tall skinny kid. Another kid just listens to a walkman as he slowly rocks, while another kid holds court with a tattered blue aluminum bat. Suddenly a 1998 BMW pulls up behind the backstop, the kids run to surround it. It's JIMMY.

Our 7 kids are awed with JIMMY's car. JIMMY tries to "shoo" them away in attempts to prevent little fingerprints on what is a glass-like finish to the car. We also see a woman in the passenger seat, it's the CUTE RECEPTIONIST from Morgan Stanley. ALONZO, the kid with the blue bat, leans in the window.
Check out coach Jimmy's whip, damn this shit is pimped.
Please guys, don't touch the car, it's new. Please you'll ruin the wax. A heavy set kid named CALVERT shoves ALONZO out of the way.

Yo coach Jimmy, here's my extra inhaler. CALVERT begins to hand JIMMY a collection of stuff.  CALVERT (cont'd) Here's my sugar babies for when my blood needs sugar, my mama says I do better when my blood's got sugar and -
What's your name again?
Calvert Jefferson Tibbs, coach Jimmy but -
Everybody listen! The kids get quiet as JIMMY speaks. JIMMY (cont'd) The guy behind you is Coach Conor, he's taking over the day to day operations. CONOR steps closer when he hears his name.
What? The tall thin kid pipes up.
That bummy guy's coach?
Coach Conor I just stopped by to give you the equipment. JIMMY pushes a button and the trunk pops open. The kids scramble for the worn army bags full of bats, balls and gloves.
Jimmy I can't do this by myself -
Here's the roster and schedule. I'm goin' to the New York office for three weeks, a training seminar.
How my gonna get my money? JIMMY is already pulling away, CONOR jogs alongside the car. JIMMY offers out the window...

Ellen will have your check every Monday. JIMMY motions to ELLEN, the CUTE RFCEPTIONIST sitting in the passenger seat. She smiles. JIMMY zooms off, raising dust from the dry lot behind the backstop. CONOR stands amidst the swirling dust and swirling kids.
CONOR has somehow managed to corral all 7 boys into the graffiti laden dugout. He attempts to take roll.
Alonzo Ray Peetes? The kid with the blue bat responds.
What's up motherfucka? The kids laugh at his funny delivery.
What position do you play?

Big Willie. More laughs.  ALONZO (cont'd) Whatever, back catcher, center field, I got mad power. I pound it to the gate yo. He exchanges a hard hand slap with MAURICE the tall lanky kid. These boys are obviously the alpha males.
Frederick Payne the second? No response as the kids all point to the short stocky kid listening to his walkman. CONOR (cont'd) What position does he play?
He says he can pitch, coach Conor, but might pitch too.
What's your name?

Calvert Jefferson Tibbs, my mama says I could play anywhere, what with my asthma and all I should probably play first. I gotta keep my sugar up too. Y'know my mama says that some boys just plain big boned -

And some boys just plain fat ass. Again ALONZO exchanges slaps with MAURICE. The kids laugh. Suddenly they get quiet as two men are standing behind CONOR. One is MATT HYLAND, a white yuppie dressed in clean coaching clothes. The other is AL CARTER a black man in a sweat suit and dress shoes. They wait for CONOR to turn around.
Hi, Matt Hyland head of the coaches committee, are you the Kikuyus?
What? ALONZO jumps up.
Yeah bitch, we the Kikuyus, whassup?
(checking his pad) Where's James Devlin from Morgan Stanley?
He's the head coach I'm assisting him, he has business out of town.
Well, you've got what? Six or seven kids here? You gotta be able to field a team or the league will drop you. CONOR could care less.
I'll tell Jimmy that-
This is Al Carter he's the commissioner of the league.
Last year was a mess we had to cancel games because we'd show up and the other team would have five kids. Waste of everybody's time.

We just wanna save everyone alotta trouble, if you can't field a team, drop out. CONOR stares incredulously at the two politicians attempting to leverage him out of a situation he has no interest in being in.

Talk to Jimmy Devlin and Morgan Stanley and submit a roster by Friday. AL CARTER and MATT HYLAND saunter off proud of their stance. CONOR looks back to the seven KIKUYUS who have heard and understand their fate. CALVERT pipes up.
Tiki and Ray-Ray wanna play. CONOR fumbles with his sheet, he struggles to read the names.
Is that Tirakian Evans and Raymont Bennet?
Yeah, Coach Conor 'dat Tiki and Ray-Ray, but Missus Wilkes ain't never gonna let them play. The kids explode in impersonations of MRS. WILKES, who from these impressions is a mean woman.
Who's Mrs. Wilkes?
She teach fifth grade at Immaculate Conception -
She's real mean Coach -
She's a old nasty lady who tell your moms everything "bout what homework you don't do, she called my moms every night last year.
And she won't let these guys play?
Coach Conor she told they moms that they can't play ball until they do these book reports.
I can tell ya, Tiki ain't doin' shit.
Ray-Ray neither, yo. Them motherfuckas is like, "quit that noise bitch". CONOR raises his bandaged hand in an attempt for control.
Can we try to cool it on the use of "Motherfuckers" and "bitch". The kids get quiet for a second. CONOR stares at his roster thinking.
Where's Immaculate Conception? Maybe I should try to talk to Mrs. Wilkes. FREDDY who has been silent the whole time pipes way up.

They all turn to FREDDY who takes off his head phones and then very earnestly offers. FREDDY (cont'd) No Coach, that bitch is one mean old motherfucka. The team laughs at FREDDY's disregard for the "Motherfucker" ban.

Alright, umh... well I gotta talk to Coach Devlin and figure this out. The sound of unbelievably heavy bass emanates from a "83 Monte Carlo that slowly prowls through the lot behind the backstop. The players on the field all stand still and watch it pass. CONOR notes the reaction from the team.
Coach it's gettin' dark, we gotta go soon.
Who's in that car.
They "folks", they local, it's cool.
Folks?
Yeah, "folks", they ain't the problem, "Disciples", they the problem. CONOR absorbs this information before addressing the team. He tries to organize the next practice as the kids are antsy to leave.
Umh...Thursday at four o'clock here. The kids have already broken into small factions as they map out their routes home.
Yo Lonzo, how you goin'?
Up Carson, to Division then across Beaumont then 27th back to Carson at Cabrini.
I was gonna go down Carson and through the school yard back to Cabrini.
My mom's meetin' me at Pizza pizza, I'm not walking by myself. CALVERT nervously runs to catch FREDDY.

Freddy, wait up, I wanna go with you to Pizza pizza. CONOR curiously watches as the kids attack the darkening landscape with military efficiency. Three separate groups tight together, trying to get safely back to the Cabrini Projects.
ALONZO and MAURICE walk shoulder to shoulder up CARSON street overly aware of everyone they see.
Wanna just cut up 25th?
Whatever, I don't always walk the folks loop, fuck the Disciples. A volley of gun fire is heard a few blocks away, the boys stop for one second.
Glock, nine millimeter. The boys continue to walk, shoulders closer trying not to appear scared.
You know about my Ka-rah-tay right?
You mean karate?

Nah, it's Ka-rah-tay, I learned it from my cousin who was in Japan in the Army. MAURICE's silence is a tacit acceptance of ALONZO's lie. ALONZO (cont'd) Lightning quick. ALONZO stops in his tracks and slaps MAURICE in the chest. MAURICE stops walking. ALONZO assumes a pose placing his hands by his ears like claws, eyes bugged wide open and standing on one foot. ALONZO (cont'd) This is the tiger, no man can defend himself from the fury of a well trained ka-rah-tay tiger man. MAURICE nods his head wanting desperately to believe that ALONZO really has uncontrollable deadly martial arts skills.
Yeah Lonzo, the tiger, I heard a that. ALONZO retracts his pose as if coming out of a trance.
Yeah, I only use the tiger when I fight like a dozen guys.
Yeah that's right.
More than that I use the bear.
Right... (a beat) What's the bear again? MAURICE looks to ALONZO who we get the feeling has exhausted his ka-rah-tay repertoire.
I can't show you, secret code of ka-rah-tay honor.

That's cool. The boys have continued down the street and have come to CARSON and 24th Street. We can see the tall buildings of the Cabrini Green Housing Project two short blocks away. Just as they're about to cross 24 they see a gang of teenagers wearing an assortment of Georgetown Hoya gear; Starter pullovers, wool caps, baseball hats. Without speaking ALONZO and MAURICE put their heads down and continue quickly up CARSON Ave.
A 1978 Toyota Celica pulls up to the curb and CALVERT gets out and we can see FREDDY and FREDDY'S MOM in the car. FREDDY'S MOM hands a small pizza box out the window.

Thanks ma'am, I'll finish it tonight. The car pulls away and CALVERT studies the four dimly lit buildings arranged in a U-shaped courtyard. He fixes on the entrance to an orange high rise 100 yards away. Jamaican music floats out of a distant window and a group of older men drink from bottles in bags at a picnic table. The asphalt circle in the middle of the four buildings is dark but we can see shadows of people moving around. Groups of young men stand on the sidewalk. Some slowly troll on B.M.X bikes watching every car for brake lights. If a car slows down they circle for a sale. CALVERT begins to walk towards the orange building, his breath is labored by asthma and fear. He sees a shadow out of the corner of his eye and he instinctively runs toward the nearest building. CALVERT busts through the lobby door of a blue building and presses his chubby frame against the cinder block wall. He pulls out his inhaler and takes two quick hits. The flame of a lighter illuminates the otherwise dark stairwell as a rail thin woman lights the end of what used to be the plastic tube of a bic pen. We now see that there's a guy with her and CALVERT goes through a door to the hallway of the first floor of the building.  CALVERT continues down the hallway and we see the doors of different apartments left open. The sound of T.V.'s squawking and babies crying accompany the toys and kids that litter the thin hall. CALVERT gets to the other end of the hall and goes in to the stairwell. CALVERT steps over a sleeping body and again ventures outside. CALVERT again fixes on the entrance to the orange building that is now only 20 yards away. He takes one more hit from his inhaler and sprints as best he can to the steps of the orange building. CALVERT bursts through the door of the orange building and immediately bounds up the stairs. He turns the corner and THREE YOUNG MEN are standing around a small radio listening to hip-hop music and sharing a 40 ounce malt liquor. CALVERT passes them with his head down and the boys don't even acknowledge him. CALVERT uses the key hanging by a shoestring around his neck to open apartment 207.
TICKY and CONOR are scalping tickets in what appears to be a dead market. Other scalpers laze about and compete for the same sales. TICKY and CONOR are mid- conversation.
What?
Nothing.
Fuck you.
I just can't believe you're going to some school in the projects to beg some old nun for ball players?  A HEAVY SET MAN in a Blackhawks jacket approaches them. The HEAVY
I need three in the blues for 50.
(to the man) Fuck you 85, (to Ticky) I got no choice Jimmy's payin' my juice with Duffy, if I don't field a team the league drops us, I don't get my money. SET MAN re-approaches.
I got 65 take it or leave it.
You take it, and shove it up your ass -
Yeah, 85 you fat fucker. (to Ticky) These kids are scary, they all live in Cabrini, they got gangs, I gotta get out.
Yeah, you gotta get out, Cabrini's a shithole those kids are killers. They'll kill ya, maybe not today but-
Could you tap your mom for a coupla bucks 'till I can-
Mom's not havin' it, she cut me off. HEAVY SET MAN makes a last effort.
C'mon guys it's my kid's birthday, 70 for the three in the blues.
Would you kiss my ass already? Can't you see we're tryin' to figure somethin' out here? I feel like smackin' you in the head, I do.
Gimme 75. The HEAVY SET MAN digs deep, obviously going over his budget.
Jesus, I heard that Baby Bop ain't even in this show.

Why don't you not worry about Baby Bop. TICKY peels off the three tickets from an efficiently arranged wad. CONOR (cont'd) I'll give you a baby bop in the head. The HEAVY SET MAN scampers away, his illegal transaction complete. CONOR reflects to TICKY. CONOR (cont'd) What's Baby Bop?
Well Barney's the big dinosaur right?
Yeah. TICKY and CONOR start walking towards the Civic Center, we begin pulling back to a wide shot.
Well Baby Bop is like this fuckin' uh, what d'ya call it...baby purple dinosaur.
No shit, dinosaurs on ice.
And they skate around with that broad from the Olympics with the horsey face? As we go wider we see the marquee for the Civic Center. It reads, "Barney and Friends on Ice".
The train thins as it continues south to Cabrini. We watch CONOR who tries not to make eye contact with the other passengers who all appear to be going nowhere in particular.
CONOR exits the train and lights a cigarette. He goes down the steps of the platform. He looks out of place.
CONOR takes a moment to bolster his courage. He takes in the sights and sounds of the playground that is  overrun with boys and girls screaming with after school energy. He heads inside.
